symbolism.celestialEarthly: The principle 'As above, so below' - celestial events reflected divine intentions that would manifest on earth
symbolism.binaryOpposition: Omens were classified as favorable (≈°ulmu) or unfavorable (lumnu), often with apotropaic rituals prescribed to avert negative predictions
symbolism.divineWriting: Signs in nature, organs, and sky were understood as divine writing - the gods communicated through the created world
symbolism.liver: Considered the seat of life and emotions, the liver was the organ most directly connected to divine will. Its complex anatomy allowed for numerous interpretations.

name: Babylonian Divination

historicalContext.origins: Divination practices in Mesopotamia date to the 3rd millennium BCE. The Old Babylonian period (c. 2000-1600 BCE) saw the systematization of omen series and training of professional diviners.
historicalContext.royalMonopoly: Extispicy was primarily a royal prerogative - the king regularly consulted diviners before military campaigns, construction projects, and important decisions
historicalContext.peakPeriod: Neo-Assyrian and Neo-Babylonian periods (c. 911-539 BCE) when divination was highly developed, with vast libraries of omen texts at Nineveh and Babylon
historicalContext.influence: Babylonian divination, especially astrology, profoundly influenced Greek, Roman, Persian, and later Islamic astronomical and astrological traditions
historicalContext.libraries: King Ashurbanipal's library at Nineveh contained thousands of omen tablets, preserved when the library burned in 612 BCE, baking the clay tablets and preserving them for modern discovery

description: The systematic practice of interpreting divine signs through various methods including extispicy (liver divination), astrology, dream interpretation, and omens. Divination was the primary means of communication with the divine realm, used to discern the will of gods like Marduk and Shamash.

sections.title: Description

methods.organs: Liver (primary), gall bladder, coils of intestines, lungs, heart
methods.features: Color, texture, size, markings, abnormalities, divisions, and positions of organs
methods.description: Examination of animal entrails, especially the liver, which was considered the seat of life and divine communication. The most prestigious form of divination.

methods.omens: Lunar eclipses, planetary positions, Venus phenomena, comets, meteors, weather signs
methods.description: Observation of astronomical phenomena including planetary movements, eclipses, halos, and unusual events. Believed celestial events presaged earthly ones.
Analysis of dreams as divine messages. Dream omen manuals catalogued dream symbols and their meanings.

Interpreting patterns and movements of incense smoke

methods.description: Interpreting the significance of malformed newborns (human or animal) as divine messages
methods.text: Extensive omen series cataloguing birth abnormalities and their meanings

methods.description: Signs from everyday occurrences, animal behavior, encounters on the road, sounds, and natural phenomena

prayers.title: Invocation to Shamash
prayers.context: Prayer spoken before extispicy to invoke the sun god Shamash (god of justice and truth) and Adad (storm god associated with divination)
prayers.text: O Shamash, lord of judgment, O Adad, lord of divination, I stand before you. Accept my offering, hear my prayer, and reveal the truth through this sacrifice.

modernPractice: While Babylonian divination is not practiced today, its influence persists in Western astrology, tarot, and other divinatory traditions. The zodiac, horoscopy, and association of planets with earthly events all derive from Babylonian celestial divination.

steps.details: The baru priest underwent ritual purification, donned clean garments, and prepared the sacred space. The petitioner stated their question clearly.
A sheep or goat was sacrificed according to precise ritual procedures. The animal's acceptance by the gods was noted through its behavior during sacrifice.
The baru carefully examined the liver, gall bladder, lungs, and intestines, noting any irregularities, markings, or unusual features. Each part of the liver had symbolic meaning.
The diviner consulted standardized omen compendia (like the BƒÅr√ªtu series) that catalogued thousands of signs and their meanings: 'If the liver shows X feature, then Y will occur.'
The baru synthesized multiple signs, considering favorable and unfavorable omens together, then pronounced the divine answer to the petitioner's question.
Scribes recorded the question, method, omens observed, and interpretation on clay tablets for the royal archives.
Astrologer-priests observed the positions and movements of planets (especially Jupiter, Venus, Mars), lunar eclipses, and unusual celestial phenomena, consulting the En≈´ma Anu Enlil series.
